thread.title: 'Golden Decade' Hopes As Osborne Visits China
thread.title_full: 'Golden Decade' Hopes As Osborne Visits China

title: 'Golden Decade' Hopes As Osborne Visits China
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sun, Sep 20, 2015, 09:04 BST - UK Markets closed 'Golden Decade' Hopes As Osborne Visits China By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 1 hour 11 minutes ago View Photo 

Interested in China? Or bored to pieces with it? Either way, you're going to hear a lot more about the world's emerging economic powerhouse in the coming days. 
George Osborne is in Beijing for his biggest trade visit to the country yet. 
He has taken with him a host of financiers, chief executives, some cultural leaders and even one or two journalists. 
We touched down in China's capital this morning to begin a week-long journey across the country, from Beijing and Shanghai in the east to Chengdu, Urumqi and its far west reaches. 
It is all intended to set up what the Chancellor calls "a golden decade of UK-China relations". 
There will be announcements about cultural exchanges and exhibits, new investment projects and financial deals. 
Why all the noise? It’s all part of the Government’s attempts to try to boost its trade with China. 
For despite the fact that China’s contribution to world GDP has risen from under 2% in 1990 to almost 15% last year, it still only accounts for 3.6% of the UK’s exports. 
That makes it Britain's sixth-biggest goods export market, somewhere beneath Belgium. 
The Chancellor is determined to push China higher. 
And walking around Beijing you can understand why. 
This is a thriving metropolis full of increasingly wealthy consumers who are now finally starting to spend. 
The Chancellor's hope is that they spend this money on British luxury goods. 
However, he is faced with a number of problems. 
One is that Chinese firms are competing desperately with British ones for business on their own soil. 
Another is that China has its own problems. 
Its stock market crash last month was a sign that the country’s economic bubble may be starting to burst. 
There are some who fear its breakneck growth, fuelled largely by borrowing, could end in an almighty slump. 
Those jitters have not stopped the Chancellor’s long-planned visit. 
But they are likely to come up repeatedly as he meets with Chinese leaders and businesspeople.
